metadata.titleEn: Ground observation dataset of corn biomass, vegetation coverage, leaf area index and plant height at Daman station in the middle reaches of Heihe River (growth period in 2019)
metadata.description: This dataset is a continuous ground observation data of vegetation coverage (%), biomass (g/plant), leaf area index (LAI) and plant height (cm) of seed corn during the growing period in 2019 at Daman Station ( 38.85551N,100.37223E)in the middle reaches of the Heihe River. Ground observation was carried out in three sample plots.  Biomass observation included fresh and dry aboveground biomass, fresh and dry underground biomass (fresh and dry root weight), vegetation coverage was observed by digital camera, leaf area index was observed by LAI 2200, and plant height was observed by tape measure. The observation period was from May 17 to September 23, 2019, in which LAI started from June 11. Observation parameters were observed every 5 days before July 31 and every 10 days thereafter, and a total of 20 observations (LAI was 15) were carried out during the whole growing period. The dataset can provide data basis for inversion and validation of surface vegetation parameters.
metadata.instructions: Observation data are stored in Excel form. The file name is yyyy.xlsm, where yyyy stands for year.

background: Crop biomass is one of the most important biophysical indicators of crop growth. The accurate and efficient estimation of the regional crop biomass at different growth stages is of great importance in guiding crop management decision making, such as in effective fertilization, water irrigation, weeding, and pest and disease management. In addition, as an important aspect of biomass energy, the accurate estimation of crop biomass contributes to the rational and effective utilization of biomass energy. Moreover, effective estimates of crop biomass during the growing season could play a key role in crop yield prediction. The traditional crop biomass estimation method is mainly based on field measurements, which include destructive field sampling, laboratory drying and weighting. The traditional methods are relatively accurate, but they are labor intensive and time consuming. Moreover, the sparse nature of space makes it impossible to provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales. Thus, it is impossible to acquire the regional crop biomass via ground measurements alone. The satellite remote sensing technique is a unique and useful method for crop biomass monitoring in a repeatable manner due to the valuable information it provides on vegetation parameters, high spatial coverage and long time series, which effectively compensates for the deficiency of traditional biomass estimation methods. Previous studies have revealed that remote sensing is a reliable and effective technique to obtain biophysical and biochemical crop information.
research objective: In this paper, four machine learning models, namely random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), artificial neural network (ANN), and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) were adopted to estimate the seasonal corn biomass based on field observation data and moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (MODIS) reflectance data from 2012 to 2019 in the middle reaches of the Heihe River basin, China.
challenges: This is currently one of the major challenges for agricultural researchers and farm managers.
methods: In this study, the corn biomass was estimated based on daily MODIS datasets with a 500 m spatial resolution combined with long-term ground observation data in the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin, and four machine learning algorithms, namely RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost, were adopted to predict the biomass. Large, relatively homogeneous areas, which mainly functioned as corn growing areas, were selected as the sample sites. According to a field survey of the sample sites, a total of sixteen sites were selected in 2012, and three sites were selected for field measurement purposes every year from 2013 to 2019. One to three plots for each sample site were chosen for further biomass observation, with each plot covering an area of 100 m ×100 m. All selected plants in each plot were collected, and the roots of the corn plants were washed. The fresh weight was measured, after which the plants were transported to the laboratory, chopped into easy-to-dry segments, and dried in an oven at 85°C for 48–72 h until a constant dry biomass was obtained. MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products from May to September from 2012 to 2019 were analyzed in this study. The forward feature selection method was implemented to choose the most influential variables, which is an iterative method starting from the condition of no model features. In each iteration, we add a given feature that best improves the model until the addition of a new variable does not further improve the model performance. The RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost algorithms were adopted in this study. R software was used to implement the above four machine learning algorithms with the randomForest, kernlab, brnn, and xgboost packages. In this study, the caret package in R software was applied to tune the parameters of the above four machine learning algorithms. The 10-fold cross validation method was implemented to evaluate the performance of the above four machine learning models due to the small number of training samples.
dataset: MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products from May to September from 2012 to 2019 were analyzed in this study. A total of sixteen sites were selected in 2012, and three sites were selected for field measurement purposes every year from 2013 to 2019. One to three plots for each sample site were chosen for further biomass observation, with each plot covering an area of 100 m ×100 m.
findings: The results indicated that the corn biomass was suitably estimated (the coefficient of determination (R2) was between 0.72 and 0.78) with the four machine learning models. The XGBoost model performed better than the other three models (R2 = 0.78, root mean squared error (RMSE) = 2.86 t/ha and mean absolute error (MAE) = 1.86 t/ha). Moreover, the RF model was an effective method (R2 = 0.77, RMSE = 2.91 t/ha and MAE = 1.91 t/ha), with a performance comparable to that of the XGBoost model.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'machine learning models' in estimating crop biomass?
Definition.Answer: Machine learning models, such as random forest, support vector machine, artificial neural network, and extreme gradient boosting, are used to estimate crop biomass by analyzing data from sources like remote sensing and ground observations. These models help in predicting biomass efficiently by processing and learning from large datasets, offering an alternative to traditional field measurement methods.

Comparison.Question: How do the ground-based observation methods for measuring corn biomass, such as destructive field sampling, compare to satellite remote sensing techniques in terms of accuracy and efficiency?
Comparison.Answer: Ground-based observation methods like destructive field sampling and laboratory drying are accurate but labor-intensive and time-consuming. In contrast, satellite remote sensing provides valuable information on vegetation parameters with high spatial coverage and long time series, offering a more efficient method for monitoring crop biomass on a regional scale.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences between using machine learning algorithms like random forest and XGBoost for estimating corn biomass compared to traditional field-based measurements?
Comparison.Answer: Machine learning algorithms, such as random forest and XGBoost, leverage satellite data and provide estimates with a high coefficient of determination (R2 between 0.72 and 0.78), indicating good performance. These methods offer scalability and efficiency compared to traditional field-based measurements, which are limited in spatial coverage and labor-intensive.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of acquiring corn biomass data using traditional methods differ from those encountered when using satellite remote sensing and machine learning approaches?
Comparison.Answer: Traditional methods face challenges such as being labor-intensive, time-consuming, and limited in spatial coverage, making it difficult to obtain regional data. In contrast, satellite remote sensing and machine learning approaches provide extensive spatial coverage and leverage repeatable data collection over time, though they may require complex data processing and model tuning to ensure accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of traditional field sampling with remote sensing data enhance the accuracy and efficiency of crop biomass estimation?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration allows for the combination of detailed, accurate ground measurements with the broad spatial coverage and repeatability of remote sensing, thus compensating for the spatial limitations of traditional methods and enhancing the overall estimation process.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the necessity of using both ground and satellite data for crop biomass estimation in the Heihe River basin?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The accurate estimation of crop biomass is crucial for effective crop management and biomass energy utilization. Ground measurements alone are labor-intensive, time-consuming, and cannot provide comprehensive regional understanding. Satellite remote sensing offers valuable vegetation parameters, high spatial coverage, and long time series, which effectively complement ground measurements and address the limitations of traditional biomass estimation methods.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might machine learning algorithms be preferred for estimating seasonal corn biomass over traditional methods in agricultural research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Traditional methods based on field measurements are accurate but labor-intensive and time-consuming, making them unsuitable for large-scale regional analysis. Machine learning algorithms, combined with satellite data, provide a more efficient and scalable approach to estimate biomass at different growth stages, offering improved model performance and enabling effective regional crop management.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in obtaining accurate regional crop biomass estimates in agricultural research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: One major challenge is the sparse nature of ground measurements, which makes it difficult to provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales. Additionally, the labor-intensive nature of field sampling and the need for long-term observation data pose significant hurdles. Satellite remote sensing and machine learning techniques are used to address these challenges by providing repeatable, large-scale data and efficient estimation methods.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the possible consequences of using satellite remote sensing techniques in estimating crop biomass compared to traditional field measurements?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Satellite remote sensing techniques provide valuable information on vegetation parameters with high spatial coverage and long time series, which effectively compensates for the deficiency of traditional biomass estimation methods. This allows for a repeatable and comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales, which is not possible with ground measurements alone.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using forward feature selection in the development of machine learning models for biomass estimation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using forward feature selection helps in identifying the most influential variables for the development of machine learning models, improving model performance by iteratively adding features that best enhance the model. This method ensures the creation of more accurate and efficient models, as seen in the improved performance of models like XGBoost and RF in estimating corn biomass.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to integrate ground-based measurements with satellite remote sensing data in the monitoring of crop biomass?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating ground-based measurements with satellite remote sensing data is important because it provides comprehensive information on vegetation parameters, ensuring high spatial coverage and long time series. This approach effectively compensates for the limitations of traditional biomass estimation methods, which cannot provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of conducting field surveys and selecting sample sites for biomass observation in agricultural studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives of conducting field surveys and selecting sample sites for biomass observation are to obtain accurate and reliable data on crop biomass, which can be used to train and validate predictive models. This data collection method helps to ensure that the selected sample sites are representative of the larger area being studied, facilitating the development of models that can be generalized to regional scales.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in collecting and measuring corn biomass using ground observation techniques in agricultural research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves selecting sample sites and plots for biomass observation, collecting all selected plants in each plot, washing the roots, measuring the fresh weight, transporting the plants to the laboratory, chopping them into easy-to-dry segments, and drying them in an oven at 85°C for 48–72 hours until a constant dry biomass is obtained.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is vegetation cover percentage determined using digital camera methods during field observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Vegetation cover percentage is determined by using a digital camera to capture images of the target area. These images are then analyzed to quantify the percentage of ground covered by vegetation, providing a measure of vegetation density and distribution.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What machine learning techniques are utilized to estimate crop biomass from satellite remote sensing data, and what is the process for selecting influential variables?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Machine learning techniques such as random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), artificial neural network (ANN), and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) are used to estimate crop biomass. The forward feature selection method is implemented to choose the most influential variables, starting from no model features and iteratively adding the feature that best improves the model until no further improvement is made.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or technologies enable the accurate estimation of crop biomass using remote sensing techniques?
Enablement.Answer: Satellite remote sensing techniques enable the accurate estimation of crop biomass by providing valuable information on vegetation parameters with high spatial coverage and long time series, which effectively compensates for the deficiencies of traditional biomass estimation methods.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies or conditions enable the collection of continuous ground observation data for crop growth analysis during a growing season?
Enablement.Answer: Continuous ground observation data for crop growth analysis during a growing season is enabled by a combination of methodologies such as using digital cameras for vegetation coverage, LAI 2200 for leaf area index, and manual measurement tools like tape measures for plant height, conducted systematically over multiple observation periods.

Expectation.Question: Why might remote sensing techniques be expected to improve the efficiency of crop biomass estimation compared to traditional field measurement methods?
Expectation.Answer: Remote sensing techniques offer high spatial coverage and long time series data, allowing for repeatable and comprehensive monitoring of vegetation parameters, which effectively compensates for the labor-intensive and time-consuming nature of traditional field measurement methods.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to acquire regional crop biomass estimates using only ground measurements?
Expectation.Answer: Ground measurements are labor-intensive and time-consuming, and their sparse nature makes it difficult to provide comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales, necessitating the use of remote sensing or other methods to achieve regional estimates.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you think data collection methods using digital cameras, LAI meters, and measuring tapes are in capturing the biophysical properties of crops compared to satellite remote sensing techniques?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods using digital cameras, LAI meters, and measuring tapes are relatively accurate for capturing biophysical properties of crops at a localized level. However, they are labor-intensive and time-consuming, making them less efficient for regional coverage. In contrast, satellite remote sensing techniques provide high spatial coverage and long time series data, effectively compensating for the deficiencies of traditional methods by providing valuable information on vegetation parameters at a larger scale.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the potential for MODIS datasets to be used in long-term crop biomass monitoring, considering spatial resolution and data availability?
Judgmental.Answer: MODIS datasets hold significant potential for long-term crop biomass monitoring due to their ability to provide consistent, repeatable observations over large areas with a 500 m spatial resolution. Their availability over extended periods allows for the analysis of temporal trends and patterns in crop biomass. However, the spatial resolution might limit the detection of fine-scale variations, and complementary ground observations are necessary to validate and refine the estimates obtained from MODIS data.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the use of digital cameras for vegetation coverage measurement compares to other methods for data accuracy and efficiency.
Assertion.Answer: The use of digital cameras for measuring vegetation coverage involves capturing images and analyzing them to determine the percentage of coverage. It is a non-destructive and relatively quick method compared to traditional techniques. However, the accuracy can vary depending on the resolution of the camera and the methodology applied in image analysis.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential improvements in data collection methods for estimating crop biomass using a combination of ground observations and remote sensing technologies.
Request/Directive.Answer: The current data collection method for estimating crop biomass involves ground-based observations and remote sensing technologies like MODIS datasets. Improvements could include integrating more advanced sensors for higher resolution data, employing UAVs for aerial imagery, or using additional satellite data to enhance temporal and spatial coverage. These methods can increase the accuracy and efficiency of biomass estimation by providing more comprehensive and detailed datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose strategies for enhancing dataset availability and quality for crop biomass estimation in the context of the Heihe River basin's agricultural landscape.
Request/Directive.Answer: To enhance dataset availability and quality for crop biomass estimation, strategies could include expanding the number of observation sites and plots, ensuring a diverse representation of different crop growth conditions. Collaborations with remote sensing agencies to access additional satellite data can improve spatial and temporal resolution. Implementing automated data collection techniques through IoT sensors and drones could provide real-time data, while machine learning can be utilized to refine and validate datasets, ensuring higher accuracy and reliability.
